pull.title: doc: how to update a subtree
pull.body: We have instructions on how to verify a subtree update, but not on how to perform one.

events.body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--006a51241073e994b41acfe9ec718e94-->
### Code Coverage & Benchmarks
For details see: https://corecheck.dev/bitcoin/bitcoin/pulls/33568.
<!--021abf342d371248e50ceaed478a90ca-->

| Type | Reviewers |
| ---- | --------- |
| ACK | [yuvicc](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/33568#issuecomment-3380164166), [janb84](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/33568#pullrequestreview-3313922400), [furszy](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/33568#pullrequestreview-3314862355) |

If your review is incorrectly listed, please react with ðŸ‘Ž to this comment and the bot will ignore it on the next update.
<!--5faf32d7da4f0f540f40219e4f7537a3-->
Looks good to me, this matches what I run to get experimental secp branches. I think @furszy 's comment should be addressed then this should be good to go.

verification.payload:
tree d7439fef9dfec47a6fae83cb5c8b3e70a1807450
parent 919e6d01e93a57d991ed456bc67c43605583ada8

doc: how to update a subtree

events.message: doc: how to update a subtree

events.body:
ACK a1226bc760c70a22ef4a197d5690aca4d83cb74c

This will be useful for new devs while verifying the subtree.

ACK a1226bc760c70a22ef4a197d5690aca4d83cb74c

This pr adds a section to subtrees. This section describes how to verify or update a subtree ( commands etc). Adding of this section will help new contributors do a subtrees update without spending time to search how to do this. 

Added small NIT to add a subsection header, to better subdivide the section. Feel free to ignore.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1119,6 +1119,12 @@ to check a subtree directory for consistency with its upstream repository.
 
 The tool instructions also include a list of the subtrees managed by Bitcoin Core.
 
+To update a subtree, follow the instructions for adding it as a remote and then:
+
+```sh
+git subtree pull --prefix=src/ipc/libmultiprocess libmultiprocess master --squash
comments.body:
Need to add the remote first. E.g.
```
git remote add libmultiprocess <repo_URL>
git subtree pull --prefix=src/ipc/libmultiprocess libmultiprocess master --squash
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1119,6 +1119,12 @@ to check a subtree directory for consistency with its upstream repository.
 
 The tool instructions also include a list of the subtrees managed by Bitcoin Core.
 
+To update a subtree, follow the instructions for adding it as a remote and then:
+
+```sh
+git subtree pull --prefix=src/ipc/libmultiprocess libmultiprocess master --squash
comments.body: That's explained in the linter doc that's linked right above, but I can duplicate it if needed.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1119,6 +1119,12 @@ to check a subtree directory for consistency with its upstream repository.
 
 The tool instructions also include a list of the subtrees managed by Bitcoin Core.
 
+To update a subtree, follow the instructions for adding it as a remote and then:
+
+```sh
+git subtree pull --prefix=src/ipc/libmultiprocess libmultiprocess master --squash
comments.body: Might be good to duplicate for the avoidance of doubt.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1119,6 +1119,12 @@ to check a subtree directory for consistency with its upstream repository.
 
 The tool instructions also include a list of the subtrees managed by Bitcoin Core.
 
+To update a subtree, follow the instructions for adding it as a remote and then:
+
+```sh
+git subtree pull --prefix=src/ipc/libmultiprocess libmultiprocess master --squash

@@ -1119,6 +1119,19 @@ to check a subtree directory for consistency with its upstream repository.
 
 The tool instructions also include a list of the subtrees managed by Bitcoin Core.
 
+To fully verify or update a subtree, add it as a remote:
+
+```sh
+git remote add --fetch libmultiprocess https://github.com/bitcoin-core/libmultiprocess.git
comments.body: No need to add the `--fetch` option. You added a `git fetch` below.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1119,6 +1119,19 @@ to check a subtree directory for consistency with its upstream repository.
 
 The tool instructions also include a list of the subtrees managed by Bitcoin Core.
 
+To fully verify or update a subtree, add it as a remote:
+
+```sh
+git remote add --fetch libmultiprocess https://github.com/bitcoin-core/libmultiprocess.git
comments.body: You only need to add it as a remote once, but each subsequent update requires a fetch. I'll drop `--fetch` from the first command though.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1119,6 +1119,19 @@ to check a subtree directory for consistency with its upstream repository.
 
 The tool instructions also include a list of the subtrees managed by Bitcoin Core.
 
+To fully verify or update a subtree, add it as a remote:
comments.body:
```suggestion
### Updating subtrees

To fully verify or update a subtree, add it as a remote:
```

NIT add a sub heading to better indicate it's a subsection. This will help the reader in finding the section and it will nicely bind the section together.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1119,6 +1119,19 @@ to check a subtree directory for consistency with its upstream repository.
 
 The tool instructions also include a list of the subtrees managed by Bitcoin Core.
 
+To fully verify or update a subtree, add it as a remote:
comments.body: But then I have to move the text below this too, or add even more paragraphs. So going to leave it as is for now.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1119,6 +1119,19 @@ to check a subtree directory for consistency with its upstream repository.
 
 The tool instructions also include a list of the subtrees managed by Bitcoin Core.
 
+To fully verify or update a subtree, add it as a remote:
+
+```sh
+git remote add --fetch libmultiprocess https://github.com/bitcoin-core/libmultiprocess.git

@@ -1119,6 +1119,12 @@ to check a subtree directory for consistency with its upstream repository.
 
 The tool instructions also include a list of the subtrees managed by Bitcoin Core.
 
+To update a subtree, follow the instructions for adding it as a remote and then:
+
+```sh
+git subtree pull --prefix=src/ipc/libmultiprocess libmultiprocess master --squash
comments.body: It's actually not necessary to add it as a remote. You can give the repo url directly and it will fetch as needed. This avoids adding a bunch of unnecessary refs to your repo.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1119,6 +1119,12 @@ to check a subtree directory for consistency with its upstream repository.
 
 The tool instructions also include a list of the subtrees managed by Bitcoin Core.
 
+To update a subtree, follow the instructions for adding it as a remote and then:
+
+```sh
+git subtree pull --prefix=src/ipc/libmultiprocess libmultiprocess master --squash
comments.body: We also recommend this for the verification process and I find it much more convenient than looking up the full URL. I haven't run out of refs :-)
